summary: This is a Law360 White Collar newsletter from July 31, 2019. The lead story reports that an alleged Jeffrey Epstein victim accused right-wing personality Michael Cernovich and Harvard Law professor Alan Dershowitz of using a request for legal fees to intimidate her, prompting an apology from Cernovich. The newsletter also contains summaries of numerous other white-collar crime and legal industry news items.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the central figure whose alleged victim is making accusations against others. He is the subject of the lead news story.

persons.name: Michael Cernovich
persons.context: Accused by an alleged Epstein victim of attempting to intimidate her by requesting she pay costs in a Second Circuit appeal. He later apologized and distanced himself from Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Accused, along with Michael Cernovich, by an alleged Epstein victim of using a request for legal fees to intimidate her.

persons.name: Jed S. Rakoff
persons.context: Sentenced a French jeweler to five months in prison for insider trading.

persons.name: Sebastian Pinto-Thomaz
persons.context: Provided an inside tip to a French jeweler who was later sentenced for insider trading.

persons.name: Patricia Hamed
persons.context: Author of an expert analysis piece arguing that effective compliance programs should look beyond DOJ guidance.

connections.description: Associated in the alleged victim's accusation that they were jointly attempting to intimidate her through legal fee requests. Cernovich later apologized and distanced himself from Dershowitz.
Implied connection as Dershowitz is accused by an alleged Epstein victim of being part of an intimidation effort. Context suggests Dershowitz was involved in legal matters related to Epstein.
Pinto-Thomaz provided an inside trading tip to the jeweler, who acted on it and was convicted.

events.title: Epstein Accuser Accuses Dershowitz and Cernovich of Intimidation
events.description: An alleged Jeffrey Epstein victim publicly states that a request for her to pay legal costs in a Second Circuit appeal is an attempt by Michael Cernovich and Alan Dershowitz to intimidate her.

events.title: Sentencing of French Jeweler in Insider Trading Case
events.description: Manhattan U.S. District Judge Jed S. Rakoff sentences a French jeweler to five months in prison for trading on an inside tip from former S&P analyst Sebastian Pinto-Thomaz.

keyFacts: An alleged Jeffrey Epstein victim accused Michael Cernovich and Alan Dershowitz of using a request for legal fees to bully and intimidate her.
Michael Cernovich apologized and distanced himself from Alan Dershowitz following the accusation.
The document is a Law360 newsletter primarily focused on white-collar crime and legal industry news, with the Epstein-related story as the lead item.
The document references a legal proceeding in the Second Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals involving the alleged victim.
The newsletter includes numerous other unrelated legal news summaries, indicating the Epstein story was one of many current topics.
